awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Microscale processes controlling speciation and transformation of phosphorus in soils
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
Phosphorus (P) plays a pivotal role in the often-competing demands of food and safeguarding water quality. Chesapeake Bay is a national treasure and the nation's first estuary targeted by Congress for restoration.  Improved understanding of the composition and the amount of P in the watershed leading to the Bay will enhance our ability to predict the potential risk of movement of P from forest, agricultural, and urban sources to the Bay waters. Scientific findings from this project will contribute to decades of work conducted by the Chesapeake Bay Program, US Geological Survey, and US Environmental Protection Agency in the Bay restoration plan. The PI and a graduate student from the University of Delaware (UD) will work with scientists at the California Institute of Technology to use a suite of sophisticated instrumentation that will determine the specific forms and concentrations of P in soils and waters. This work will greatly improve the current understanding of the complex processes that govern the environmental fate of P in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, and will enable the PI to employ techniques that are not available at the home institution.

Technical Description
Multi-scale interactions among forms of P and processes in soils and waters that vary across spatial and temporal scales call for a toolbox of advanced and innovative analytical methods capable of providing P structural information, which can connect the structure to chemical reactivity and transformation pathways. This research aims to identify the mechanisms of formation and transformation of different P pools in soils and its transport to open waters. It will utilize advanced analytical techniques, including spatially resolved electron microprobe analysis (EMPA), secondary ion mass spectrometry (nanoSIMS and magnetic SIMS), and laser ablation isotope mass spectrometer (LA-IRMS). In addition, a series of theoretical and experimental developments in light isotope systematics will be applied to identify and interpret microscale P speciation, physico-chemical association and in situ distribution of phosphate oxygen isotopes and their interrelationship in short- and long-term soil incubation as well as in soil chronosequence studies. This fellowship will maximize the PI's research productivity and leadership in several novel isotope techniques, and the knowledge and experience gained will catalyze new research fronts in the future. Findings from the project will be provided to the UD Cooperative Extension and other state and local agencies for their collective efforts to minimize the loss of nutrients from agricultural soils and to help achieve pollutant reduction goals.

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this research was to identify the microscale processes controlling chemical forms and isotope compositions of phosphorus (P) and thus track the transfer and transformation of P in soil compartments. This project used advanced analytical techniques for spatial, structural, and isotopic analysis of organic P compounds and their association in soil matrices.

 This fellowship provided PI a new training opportunity at the California Institute of Technology (CalTech) on using advanced analytical techniques, nanoSIMS and Orbitrap MS/MS, for isotope analysis of phosphate. The PI received mentoring from the host, and the collaborative relationships developed will continue beyond project years.

 The new Orbitrap-MS/MS based stable isotope measurement method developed is capable of measuring the naturally abundant isotopes in organic phosphorus compounds. Results from selected compounds confirmed that oxygen isotopes from targeted moieties could be measured to acceptable precision and reproducibility. This is a technological breakthrough because currently available methods cannot analyze isotopes of organic phosphorus compounds. This development will continue to be an engine for catalyzing innovation and further research. Refining acquisition parameters for organic P species in soils with different matrices using 1D and 2D NMR have provided independent confirmation on the speciation of molecules identified from the Orbitrap method.

 This project partially aided in establishing a new isotope facility, the Environmental Isotope Science (EIS) Center, at the University of Delaware. This is the central facility for the university and is providing research and training opportunities to faculty and graduate students at the university and institutions in the region on using state-of-the-art isotope analyses of various materials, including nutrients, soils, and waters. This facility continues to serve the research needs of diverse researchers, connect communities of scientists for environmental isotope areas. It will continue to catalyze future collaborations, including supporting MRI proposals and housing new isotope mass spectrometers.

 Collaborations made to the US and foreign scientists from this award are burgeoning and continue to benefit future research. These collaborations will aid in the separation and identification of organic P compounds in different environmental matrices, algorithm on isotope data analysis, and refining synthesis of labeled organic compounds.

 The outcomes of this project are published in one book chapter, eight peer-reviewed publications, and two manuscripts (under review). Further, the research outcomes were presented in four keynote talks, five invited talks, and six volunteered presentations in professional society meetings held in the US, Europe, and South America.

 Training opportunities provided to graduate and postdoctoral associates partially involved in this project enhanced their skills and aided in achieving higher success in their careers as postdoctoral associate and assistant professor.
